This video is somewhat misleading,    while machines DID assist with window production in the 1920s, it wasn't until the 1950s when the float glass method was perfected,  and this is why windows in old houses built prior to the 50s, have that classic ripple look.   It's not because the glass is a liquid that slowly slumps and deforms over time,  it was made that way.   Float glass uses a bath of molten tin, which melts at a much lower temperature and also happens to be more dense than molten glass, so the glass floats like oil and water, hence the name.   You really begin to appreciate all the craftsmanship and time that went into building a new house 100 years ago.  The windows,  the horsehair plaster & lathe walls, the crown molding and cabinetry,  you feel a sense of charm and nostalgia that you can can't get with new construction where they can built a home in just a few months

If you own an old house, please, DONT replace your old windows with modern vinyl ones. Let this video speak to all the hard work that went into just a single window in your house, and that's just the glass itself. The craftsmanship that went into creating the wooden sash, glaing, and hanging the windows represents skills that barely exist today, and so many people just throw it away only to replace it with generic, cheap, machine-made replacements.

Unfortunately, this video is giving out erroneous information. Window glass, while machine assisted, was NOT machine made in the 1920's and requiring no polishing. The Pilkington process was from the 1950's, which is what created 'machine made' glass that didn't require polishing. AKA float glass. The window glass in my house, built in 1947, is machine blown glass, and shows all the ripples you'd expect. (Edit - It's actually drawn glass, not blown. Blown glass would have had fewer ripples.)
